awd_titl_txt: TWC: TTP Option: Medium: Collaborative: MALDIVES: Developing a Comprehensive Understanding of Malware Delivery Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
The cybercriminal community is inarguably more organized, better resourced and more motivated than ever to perpetrate massive-scale computer infections across the Internet. The malware distribution systems that they control and operate are characterized by their use of highly specialized suppliers and commoditized malware services. As a consequence of this development, criminals with little technical expertise can deploy and administer sophisticated exploit kits, and instantiate malicious-content advertising (malvertising) campaigns that surreptitiously infect hundreds of thousands of innocent victims. The MALDIVES project is developing a new generation of technologies to provide deeper insights into how these malware distribution systems are deployed, operated, and interlinked with open web sources.

The MALDIVES project is organized as a sequence of five attack observation lablets (ATOLLs) which are collectively designed to acquire an in-depth understanding of the key stages in contemporary malware dissemination infrastructures.  The Platform Acquisition Observatory (PLATO) is focused on studying the deployment phase of the server-side infection infrastructures.  This observatory extends web-application-vulnerability mimicry systems with a dynamic exploit-kit interrogation system, and adds automated intelligence tools to understand subsequent victim infection strategies.  The Victim Enticement Scheme Evaluation Lablet (VESSEL) is focused on studying the targeting phase of the malware infection lifecycle.  It develops tools and conducts measurements on various enticement schemes, such as Search Engine Optimization (SEO) poisoning and malvertising.  The Traffic Redirection Observation Lablet (TROLL) is focused on the delivery phase and builds active and passive techniques to measure malware-related traffic redirection chains.  The Exploit Kit Interrogation Environment (EXPLORE) builds automated probes to facilitate the detection and measurement of professionally designed automated infection services.  The Defensive Strategies Investigation Lablet (DISTILL) investigates novel malware-defense capabilities based on the insights acquired from prior lablets.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overarching objective of the MALDIVES project was to improve our understanding of contemporary malware delivery mechanisms through the development of new technologies and analytics to study how malware infection infrastructures are deployed, operated, and then interlinked with open web sources to target victims.  The project was organized into five lablets: platform observation laboratory (PLATO), victim enticement laboratory (VESSEL), traffic redirection observation laboratory (TROLL), exploit kit interrogation environment (EXPLORE) and defensive strategies investigation laboratory (DISTILL).

The efforts in PLATO were focused on building a ransomware observatory and analysis infrastructure. This infrastructure has three main capabilities: (1) automatically harvesting public and private reports of ransomware incidents from the Internet; (2) gathering threat intelligence from network-level traces (e.g., DNS queries) that cover the entire lifecycle of ransomware infections (e.g., user enticement, malware distribution, ransom payment, etc.); (3) analyzing patterns and trends in ransomware operations for threat detection and prevention.  A subset of our results were published in the proceedings of TAPP 2019.

The TROLL research thrust focused on applications of machine learning identiying malware domains and access patterns both in the open web and  dark web.  Our research results were published as papers at the IEEE Security DLS Workshop 2018, KDD and AICS 2017.

THE EXPLOIT thrust developed graph-analytics and systems for detection of advanced persistent threats in real-time.  The systems emerging out of this thrust included DynaMiner, SLEUTH, HOLMES, and NAVEX which resulted in publications at DSN, EEE Security and Privacy Symposium, and a Distinguished Paper award at Usenix Security Symposium 2018.

The DISTILL thrust was focused on developing systems for facilitating automated detection and network defense. Two important contributions included the development of CLARION system for efficient provenance tracking and BASTION security enforcement kernel for policy enforcement in microservice deployments.  The latter work has been commercially transitioned to a startup.  Two papers were published in Usenix Security 2021 and Usenix ATC 2020. 

 


Last Modified: 11/24/2021
Modified by: Vinod Yegneswaran
